sourceString: We will develop an observatory to present data nationally and a dashboard for feedback to practices about their data quality and collection of virology and serology samples.
targetString: Min wurtinan kuje larugo ngam sappinugo matinolji ha nder lesdi fu be kuje windugo ngam ngewte yimbe do kude do daraja matinolji be mofturde leekuji yahde viriisji be neebam iyam.

sourceString: This is based on coding described in Table 4.
targetString: Ndu joddi do lambugo je don sappina ha Tabaal 4.

sourceString: Definite case will be presented on our dashboard as “cases” of COVID-19.
targetString: Nyau je gonga wonan sappinama ha do kuje windugo bana "nyauji" COVID-19.

sourceString: Possible cases will be presented as “Under investigation” (investigating).
targetString: Je footi wona nyauji sappinama bana "Do Lartol" (lartama).

sourceString: “Not a case” will be presented as “Excluded”.
targetString: Wonay nyau wonan sappinama as "Meedi".

sourceString: Online data has been established within the initial few weeks in the COVID-19 Observatory (Figure 5), indicating the overall number of patients and rate per 10,000 patients of cases confirmed or under investigation, as well as where the virus is excluded.
targetString: Matinolji je don do hawoo wangi ha nder arandere asaweji ha nder Larol COVID-19 (Foto 5), e don sappina limgal nyaube fu be limtol ha kunde nyaube 10 000 je don aandin mala do lartol, be wakkere je be meedi viriis.

sourceString: We have the option to move to twice weekly surveillance reports with a scope to change this to daily reporting.
targetString: Min footi waylittugo aynol batakkeji ha didi nder asawere be jaahargal saanjugo ndu ha batakkewol balde do balde.

sourceString: We will continue virology sampling from our sentinel practices, rather than discontinuing as seasonal influenza declines.
targetString: Min tokkitan be leeku yahde viriisji ha nder kude sentinel amin, do darnugo ha wakati je ndamba don usta.

sourceString: Additionally, we will recruit more surveillance practices.
targetString: Besdugo bo'o, min hoosan kude aynol buri fahin.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC virology practices will aim to undertake 200-300 nasopharyngeal swabs per week across the RCGP RSC sentinel network, collecting specimens across all age bands.
targetString: Kude RCGP RSC do gildi yidi yoosugo ndamba je wurtata gal kine 200 ha 300 ha nder asawere fu ha nder kawtirde aynol RCGP RSC, gal moftugo ndu ha geebe bi adama fu.

sourceString: In addition to the inclusion criteria for influenza virology surveillance (ILI, acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis), participating practices will take nasopharyngeal swab samples from any people showing acute symptoms of LRTI if the onset of symptoms is within 7 days.
targetString: Ha besdugo ha dabare nastinugo ngam aynol yahde viriisji ndamba (ILI, bronchitis/bronchiolitis), kude je ngadotto hoccan leekuji ndamba je kine mala daande ha kala nyaudo je don sappina mandolji nyau LRTI je nyadungel to fuddam mandolji ndu woni ha nder balde 7.

sourceString: RCGP RSC research officers and practice liaison staff will manage practices to achieve a total national sample of 200-300 swabs per week.
targetString: Ardube teffol RCGP RSC be huwobe kugal kawtal teffan dabareji ngam jukkugo lekkuji ndamba 200 ha 300 nder asawere ha nder lesdi fu.

sourceString: This could be increased if PHE modelers require more samples.
targetString: Ndu footi besda to mo je don sukli do memmugo PHE emmi leekuji feere fahin.

sourceString: Samples from each practice would be spread across the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years and older
targetString: Leekuji je hoosama ha kala kude wonan sankittama ha kunde geebeji je don sappini ndu: < dubbi 5, dubbi 5-17, dubbi 18-64, be dubbi 65 e je buri

sourceString: Samples (swabs or serum) collected will be sent via prepaid envelopes addressed to the appropriate PHE laboratory for analysis.
targetString: Leekuji (ndamba mala iyam) je moftanga neldama ha nder takardeji ha suudu lartol PHE ngam lartugo ndu.

sourceString: All samples collected will be tested for the presence of influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Leekuji fu je don mofti wonan lartama ngam larugo ndamba be COVID-19.

sourceString: Additionally, PHE will retrospectively test any influenza virology samples collected between early and mid-February 2020 for COVID-19.
targetString: Fahin, PHE laritan bo'o lartol leekuji viriis ndamba je moftotto ha kunde fuddam be cakkare Feviriye 2020 ngam COVID-19.

sourceString: Practices will still follow the PHE protocol for COVID-19 with respect to people at risk of infection who should be signposted down the containment pathway, rather than physically attend their practice.
targetString: Kude tokkitan dabare PHE COVID-19 fahin be aynugo do yimbe je footi naanga nyau man je sey lata bana mandol ha nder dabareji ustol, do wondugoo ha nder kude ndu be hoore mum.

sourceString: Direct testing of those who attend surgery remains permitted, but we have also rolled out self-swabbing at home.
targetString: Lartol ciir be'en je don walla lekkitajo nder seekkugo don jarfi, amma en meedi hoosugo lekkuji ndamba be hoore mum.

sourceString: Summary of processes are detailed in Multimedia Appendix 3.
targetString: Ramtol laahalji don limti ha Multimedia Appendix 3.

sourceString: Everyone with an ILI or a respiratory illness who contacts a GP (eg, phones for an appointment) should be asked specifically about recent travel to China and other countries flagged in current PHE advice, or if they have had contact with other people with COVID-19.
targetString: Ko moy fu be ILI mala nyau fuffugo je ewni GP (bana, ewni ngam fottugo) sey emmotto to o wadi jaahangal ha Cayna be lesde je don hollitti ha do feelore PHE je jonta, mala to be joddidi be yimbe feere je don mari COVID-19.

sourceString: If these screening enquiries are positive, the patient would be advised to not come to the practice but instead to follow the PHE flow sheet.
targetString: To lartolji je be emmi don sappina nyau, sey be feela nyaudo ngam ta o wara kude amma tokka ko don wini ha do batakkewol PHE.

sourceString: This can be by a reception or clinician staff, depending on individual practice protocol.
targetString: Ndu footi wona gal huwoobe jabbol mala jam baandu, bana ko batakkewol kude goddo do sappina.

sourceString: These calls should be coded into the GP CMR system and can be reported as part of the RCGP RSC weekly return.
targetString: Ewnolji ndu sey wona ha nder jaahargal GP CMR e footi wona bana batakkewol asawere RCGP RSC.

sourceString: We have developed training material to support this coding (Multimedia Appendix 4).
targetString: Min wurtini kujeji jaanginugo ngam wallugo be lambugo ndu (Multimedia Appendix 4).

sourceString: These include prompt cards for:
targetString: Ndu don larni karteji ngam:

sourceString: Practice reception or triage staff: for coding of any patients calling the practice with symptoms of acute respiratory infection with a history of travel to important areas based on PHE advice
targetString: Dabare jabbugo mala geebe subol: ngam mandugo nyaube je ewnatta kugal be mandolji nyau je hadata be fuffugo e je be ngadi jaahangal ha wakereji je don limti ha feeloore PHE

sourceString: Administrative staff or clinicians who code: to encourage consistent coding of results for any suspected cases, including coding of negative results for exclusion
targetString: Huwoobe ardugo mala suudu lekki je don lamba: ngam sembitinugo lambugo sappinolji ngam kala nyau je don tammi, be lambugo sappinol je wala nyau ngam meedugo.

sourceString: Practices participating in virology surveillance will opportunistically collect blood samples from patients coming into the practice for a routine blood test.
targetString: Wondugo nder kude ngam aynol yahde viriis moftan leekuji iyam ha yakke feere ha nyaube  je warata ha wakere kude ngam lartol iyam mabbe bana ko wowa.

sourceString: Patients who attend their practice for a routine blood test will be asked to provide an additional sample for serology.
targetString: Be emman ha nyaube je wondi ha kugal lartugo iyam be leeku feere fahin ngam lartugo gildi ndu.

sourceString: We have conducted initial searches within the RCGP RSC database to look at the number of full blood count (FBC) results and overall rates in adults and children (Figures 6-​-9).9).
targetString: Mi fuddi arandere teffolji nder sigorde matinolji RCGP RSC ngam sappinol limtol iyam (FBC) be limtol man fu ha maube be bikkon (Fotoji 6--9).9).

sourceString: An FBC is one of the most common tests performed, and we hope this will give an approximate indication of overall numbers of blood tests performed.
targetString: FBC lati bana gootoo ha cakka lartolji je don aandin, e min tammi ndu hokkan amin matinol do limtol lartolji iyam je en sallini fu.

sourceString: The sampling rate, per 100,000 patients was highest for children 15-17 years of age and 60 year or older in adults, with the lowest rates in children 0-4 years of age and 18-29 years of age in adults (Figures 6-​-99).
targetString: Limtol leekuji, ha nyaube 100 000 lati buri masin ha bikkon je don mari dubbi 15-17  be dubbi 60 mala je buri ha maube, be limto je buri lessugo ha bikkon dubbi 0-4 be dubbi 18-29 ha maube (Fotoji 6-​-99).

sourceString: We will provide 1000 serology baseline samples across all ages that reflect the varying rates of attendance by age.
targetString: Min hokkan leekuji neebam iyam 1000 je larnatta dubbi fu je don sappina limtol wondugo be dubbi.

sourceString: Additionally, we will test if we can obtain these all from virology practices to enhance the yield.
targetString: Ha besdugo bo'o, min tamman lartugo to en footi kebbugo dum fu ha wakkere kude lartol viriis ngam tawugo sappinol.

sourceString: A good geographical spread is important, so PHE can advise on areas where serology will most usefully be collected.
targetString: Sankittol ha do wakkere bodde don kandudum, ngam PHE footi feela ha wakkereji neebam iyam hoccotto burna.

sourceString: This will be followed by 800 samples monthly.
targetString: Ndu tokkitan be lekkuji 800 nder lewru.

sourceString: The sample will be stratified with 200 specimens for prepandemic survey (100 for monthly) in the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years or older.
targetString: Leeku wonan be ta'irdeji 200 ngam emmolji je hiddeko nyau duniyaru (100 je lewru) ha nder geebeji dubbi je don limti ndu: < dubbi 5, dubbi 5-17, dubbi 18-64, be dubbi 65 mala buri.

sourceString: The younger patients, in many practices younger than 14 years, and in nearly all for children younger than 8 years will require pediatric serology surveillance.
targetString: Nyaube je maray dubbi jur, ha nder burna wakkere kude be yottay dubbi 14, e ha burna bikkon je maray dubbi 8 sey ayna neebam iyam mabbe.

sourceString: We will develop a new request form for practices to capture recent travel and exposure to COVID-19.
targetString: Min wurtinan batakkewol emmol feere ngam hoosugo matinol jaahangal je neebay e wondugo ha wakkere COVID-19.

sourceString: We will pilot a scheme for collecting convalescent serology from people with confirmed cases and who have had an acute virology sample at the time of their infection.
targetString: Min ngadan dabare moftugo neebam iyam ha yimbe je don aandi mari nyau timmi e je don no mari leeku yahde viriis nyadungel ha wakati rabbol mabbe.

sourceString: This is to identify a carrier state in patients who have recovered from the virus but may continue shedding the virus.
targetString: Ndu ngam maandugo roondoowo ha nyaubeje nyambitti ha viriis amma footi don tokkita be hoosugo viriisji.

sourceString: If there are a small number of cases, this may assist in developing a test kit for patients to take to their own GP and explore its acceptability to patients.
targetString: To wodi limgal nyaube seeda tan, ndu footi walla nder wurtinugo kuje lartol ha nyaube ngam hebba be hoosa GP mabbe e lara jabbol nde ha nyaube.

sourceString: If there are a large number of COVID-19 cases nationally, convalescent samples could be collected from RCGP RSC practices where there are confirmed cases, with the ability to link to the full medical record.
targetString: To wodi limgal nyaube COVID-19 duddum ha nder lesdi, en footi hocca leeku yimbe je nyambitti ha wakkereji kude RCGP RSC je nyauji ndu don aandi timmi, be dabare hawtugo be bindi suudu lekki.

sourceString: This process may include checking pseudonymized NHS numbers for positive individuals at RCGP RSC practices, checking current PHE guidance regarding considerations of infectiousness for confirmed cases, and offering the patient an appointment following the previously mentioned process.
targetString: Laahal ndu footi larna lartol limtolji NHS je be saanji inde ha yimbe je don mari gildi nyau ha wakkere kude RCGP RSC, lartol fadowo PHE je jonta do ko larni rabbende nyaube je don aandi mari, e hokkugo ha nyaudo wakati ngidol bana je don limti ha laahal je sallingo.

sourceString: This needs to be carefully coordinated nationally across the network and may require PHE to ensure individuals are not contacted by multiple agencies.
targetString: Ndu yidi sey fada dum be hakkika ha do lesdi fu e footi emma PHE ngam fammugo to dowirdeji feere-feere ewnata yimbe.

sourceString: RCGP RSC could provide a useful structure to channel the initial contact once PHE has made a request.
targetString: RCGP RSC footi hokka dabare je nafatta ngam fadugo aranool ngidol ha bawo PHE ngadi emmol.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of a LRTI.
targetString: Kude RCGP RSC je don huwida ngam aynol yahde viriis ndamba je hittande fuddi wurtinugo lekkuji ha nyaube je don sappina mandolji nyauji LRTI.

sourceString: All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Leekuji fu lati lartama ngam ndamba be COVID-19.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC will explore ways to collect convalescent samples from any patients tested positive for COVID-19 through the extension of the virological surveillance.
targetString: RCGP RSC teffan dabareji moftugo leekuji ha nyabe je larti don mari nyau COVID-19 gal aynol yajjol viriisji.

sourceString: From the start, we will be carefully curating data to ensure that it can be used for future studies.
targetString: Diga fuddam, min suklan do lartugo matinolji ngam ha en huwida be man ha nder ekkitolji je warango.

sourceString: Our clinical data will be linked to virology.
targetString: Matinolji suudu lekki amin yahidan be yahde viriisji.

sourceString: We will curate our data using the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable principles.
targetString: Min lartan matinolji amin gal dabareji je mbiyotto Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable.

sourceString: To facilitate this our data set is listed with Health Data Research UK and the European Health Data Evidence Network.
targetString: Ngam latinugo ndu koydum matinolji amin don limti be Health Data Research UK be Kawtirol Sappinol Matinolji Jam Baandu Erop.

sourceString: The statistical methodology is in support of a policy approach to widespread disease outbreak, where so-called nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) are used to respond to an emerging pandemic to produce disease suppression.
targetString: Jaahargal kugal limgal don fadi siyasa dabare wangol nyau je don yajji, e kude je mbiyotto na je yimbe lekki (NPIs) don huwida ngam jabbinugo do nyau duniyaru je wangi ngam nattinugo nyau ndu.

sourceString: This policy aims to reduce contact rates in the population and thereby reduce transmission of the virus.
targetString: Dabare ngu yidi ustugo limtol ngidolji ha nder ummatore e gal ndu ustugo rabbol viriis ngal.

sourceString: To implement this the UK government has recently articulated the desire to implement population self-isolation measures.
targetString: Ngam wadugo ngu ngomna lesde UK sappini dabareji neebay je ko moy fu nder ummatore ayna hoore mada.

sourceString: By targeting the reproduction number (R) (the average number of secondary cases each case generates) and aiming to reduce the R to below 1, the policy seeks to reduce case numbers to low levels or (as seen in previous outbreaks with severe acute respiratory syndrome and Ebola) to eliminate human-to-human transmission.
targetString: Gal larugo limgal nuftugo (R) (limgal je cakkare nyaube seera je kala nyau don wada) be habdugo ustol R ha les 1, siyasa fon teffa ustugo limtolji nyaube ha les mala (bana don holli ha nyauji sallingo be sadirmaji ngam fuffugo be Ebola) ha darnugo rabbol neddol ha neddo.

sourceString: As the experience from the 2009 H1N1 pandemic has shown, NPIs can be a crucial component of pandemic mitigation.
targetString: Bana ko salli be nyau duniyaru je 2009 H1N1, NPIs footi wona dabare unstol nyau je duniyaru fu je kandudum.

sourceString: Key to the focus of our study will be the estimation of peak cases in the population and continual monitoring by data collection and modelling the potential growth and emergence of subsequent peaks in new cases as social distancing measures are relaxed.
targetString: Ko lati kandudum ha nder ekkitol amin wonan fammugo nyadol nyauji ha cakka ummatore e lartol je don tokkiti gal moftugo be hawtugo dabareji nder yahde e wurtinol nyadol ha cakka nyaube keese to bana dabareji accugo baabe ha kunde ummatore.

sourceString: There has already been publication of important disease epidemiological measures concerning the outbreak of COVID-19 in mainland China.
targetString: Wodi no timmi sappinol dabareji nyau je don rabba ngam wangol nyau COVID-19 ha lesdi Cayna.

sourceString: A further fundamental measure in pandemic dynamics is the length of time from infection to when a person is infectious to others and the mean duration of infectiousness.
targetString: Dabare feere je woni kandudum ha nder saanjol nyau ndu lati juttol wakati diga rabbol nyau ha wakati je goddo footi rabba be'en feere e pettum wakati rabbol.

sourceString: These factors, if estimated accurately, will give good predictions for the likely length of the pandemic, the final number of infected cases.
targetString: Kujeji ndu, to lari be lawol man, hokkan sappinolji bodde ngam juttol nyau duniyaru ndu, ragare limtol nyaube.

sourceString: We intend to apply approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) to (possibly spatially heterogeneous) Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR) stochastic epidemic models.
targetString: Min tammi huwida be approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) ha (footi wona jilli ha nder wakkere) sappinolji nyau rabbungel je be hoosi tan je mbiyotto Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR).

sourceString: Such techniques are highly parallelizable and have been successfully applied to many fields including disease transmission modelling.
targetString: Irin dabareji don fooda masin e be huwidi be man be kandudum ha wakkereji duddum bana ngadugo leeku rabbol nyau.

sourceString: They are particularly suited to situations where likelihood functions are absent and where more traditional approaches such as Markov chain Monte Carlo are impractical.
targetString: Be buri naffugo burna ha wakatijo je dabareji naandol wonay e je dabareji aran bana Markov chain Monte Carlo footay hokka.

sourceString: Such an approach has been demonstrated to work effectively on the ASPREN surveillance data, a network of sentinel GPs and nurse practitioners who report deidentified information on ILIs and other conditions, where issues such as missing data and the need to model the observation process itself has been successfully addressed.
targetString: Irin dabareji don holli bana footi hokka boddum ha aynol matinolji ASPREN, kawtirde sentine GPs be suklobe do jam baandu je matini matinolji je maandaka do ILIs mala nyauji feere, je kujeji bana matinolji je wonday e ngidol lartugo laahal larugo lati bodde.

sourceString: Furthermore, peaks in new cases have been estimated by distributional methods.
targetString: Fahin, nyadolji ha nyaube je keese tawama ha dabareji sankitugo.

sourceString: Estimates of the parameters of the SEIR model are tractable on large data sets because of parallelizability, and these methods have been implemented in several R libraries; we intend to use the libraries ABSEIR (deposited on GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) and abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) to estimate epidemic measures on a weekly basis.
targetString: Fopndolji dabareji SEIR footi waylitama ha do matinolji je don mauni masitin ngam yahiditugo, e dabareji ndu huwidama ha nder cuddu jaangirdeji R; min tammi huwugo be cuudi jaangirdeji ABSEIR (je jo'inama ha GitHUB: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) be abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) ngam lartugo dabareji nyau ha nder asawere.

sourceString: Since we are fitting an SIR-epidemic model in the ABC routine, we anticipate that our results will be robust against weekly case data containing relatively small counts.
targetString: Nden en don foonda sappinol nyau rabbungel SIR ha nder kude ABC, min don yaawina ngam ha sappinolji amin mara sembe do matinolji nyau ha nder asawere je don mari limtolji seeda.

sourceString: For example, see for the ABC methodology applied to the Tristan da Cunha common cold data from 1967, where counts of I (number of infectious cases) and R (number of recovered cases) are in the tens at most.
targetString: Bana sappinol, lare dabare ABC je hoccama ha nder matinolji ndamba Tristan da Cunta je 1967,  je limtolji I (limgal nyaube je don rabba) be R (limgal nyaube je nyambitti) don nder sappo do sappo burna fu.

sourceString: Finally, in addition to the above methodology we will employ the Kaplan-Meier method with two outcomes (death and recovery) to estimate the case fatality ratio.
targetString: Ha ragare man, besdugo ha dabareji je don limti ha dow, min huwidan be dabare Kaplan-Meier be sappinolji didi (mayde be nyambittol) ngam larugo limtol mayde.

sourceString: This approach is independent of the ABC methodology and will allow comparisons between estimates from the two modelling approaches to judge robustness of results.
targetString: Dabare nde jodday do dabareji ABC e footi hollina sappinolji ha kunde lartolji ha dabareji ngadol je didi ndu ngam foondugo sembe sappinolji.

sourceString: RCGP RSC's surveillance with PHE is defined as Health Protection under Regulation 3 of The Health Service (Control of Patient Information) Regulations 2002.
targetString: Aynol RCGP RSC be PHE don lati bana Fadol Jam Baandu do Tawreta 3 je The Health Service (Aynol Matinol nyaudo) Regulations 2002.

sourceString: This has been confirmed by PHE's Caldicott Guardian's Office.
targetString: Ndu jabbotto bana ni gal Caldicott Guardian's Office PHE.

sourceString: We do not see any increased risk to practices or practitioners taking part in this surveillance.
targetString: Min laray larula feere ha kude mala huwobe je don larni nder aynol ndu.

sourceString: Infection prevention and control advice will follow extant national guidance.
targetString: Fadol nyau be feelore aynol tokkitan fadol lesdi je don be sembe jonta.

sourceString: Any cases identified will be managed according to the PHE/NHS guidance in force at the time, including advice for identified contacts.
targetString: Nyauji je don maandi wonan larnama bana ko fadol PHE/NSH je don be sembe ha wakati nde yardi, be feeloji ha ngidolji je don mandi.

sourceString: However, our training will include reminders about safe handling of specimens and revision of infection control measures anticipated to be high in our practices.
targetString: Amma, ekkitol amin don larni sifturolji do huwidu be leekuji be lartol dabareji aynol nyau je don woni bana buri ha nder wakkereji kude amin.

sourceString: It is a key part of Regulation 12 about safe care and treatment, periodically inspected by the Care Quality Commission.
targetString: Lati bana kuje kandudum ha Regulation 12 do suklare be hurgol je don jam, je woni lartama be wakati gal Geebe Suklowo do Daraja.

sourceString: Travel History and Clinical Descriptors of the COVID-19 Infections
targetString: Tariya Jaahangal be Sappinoobe Mandolji nyau COVID-19

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices have been advised on the clinical coding that has been made available for COVID-19 across all CMR systems.
targetString: Kude RCGP RSC feelama ngam lambugo mandolji nyau je don ngondi ngam nyau COVID-19 ha do jaahargalji CMR fu.

sourceString: This includes information on coding of clinical descriptors (Table 4) and any recent travel history.
targetString: Ndu don larni matinolji do lambugo sappinoobe mandolji nyau (Tabaal 4) be tariya jaahangal keese.

sourceString: Establishment of Extended Virology Sampling
targetString: Wurtinol Leeku Yahde Viriis je Yajji

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of LRTI.
targetString: Kude RCGP RSC je nasti ha nder aynol yahde viriisji ndamba ha nder hittande fuddi wurtinugo leekuji nyaube je don mari mandolji nyauji LRTI.

sourceString: All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Leekuji fu je jabbotto don larti ngam ndamba be COVID-19.

sourceString: This has led to initial early identification of background spread in low-risk patients.
targetString: Ndu wadi be tawi maandirdum arandere yajjol nyau ha cakka nyaube je wala nyau feere.

sourceString: As of March 7, 2020, the surveillance system has detected 2 cases of COVID-19 in low-risk patients with no history of travel through extended virological sampling.
targetString: Ha 7 Maars 2020, dabare aynol tawi nyaube COVID-19 2 ha yimbe je maray nyauji feere e je ngaday jaahangal gal lartol leeku yahde viriisji.

sourceString: This protocol describes how we have adapted a national influenza surveillance system to monitor community spread of an unexpected infection of COVID-19.
targetString: Batakkewol ndu don limta noy min waylitti jaahargal aynol ndama ngam aynugo sankittol nyau COVID-19 ha nder ummatore.

sourceString: We have rapidly created and incorporated new codes to allow data recording, and are collecting data to monitor the effectiveness of containment strategies.
targetString: Min wurtini e hokki lambaji keese ngam hoccugo matinolji, e min don mofta matinolji ngam aynugo dabareji darnol nyau ndu.

sourceString: Through this surveillance, we intend to find out more about the epidemiology of COVID-19 in ambulatory care.
targetString: Gal aynol ndu, min ngidi fammugo duddum do nyau rabbungel je mbiyotto COVID-19 nder suklare meere.

sourceString: In particular, its rate of spread, both temporal and geographical.
targetString: Burna fu, limtol sankittol muddum, didi fu nder wakati nder wakkere.

sourceString: Our testing of low-risk patients will also inform whether the containment strategy that is based on virology testing of high-risk patients and their contacts plus self-isolation is effective.
targetString: Lartol nyaube amin je maray nyau feere matinan bo'o to dabare darnol je wondi do lartol yahde viriisji ha nyaube je don mari nyauji feere be be'en be ngidi be mabbe be wondugo ha seera do mari naffuda.

sourceString: Containment should slow the spread, and there may be benefits in the management of spread from intense surveillance.
targetString: Wondugo ha saare ustinan no sankittol, e footi ribaaji wona nder aynol do sankittolo do aynol be hakkika.

sourceString: However, there may come a point at which the virus spreads more widely into the population, as has happened in Italy.
targetString: Amma, footi tobe feere wonda je ngadatta viriis ndu sankitta laugel ha nder ummatore , bana ko salli ha Italy.

sourceString: Surveillance of low-risk patients should inform when we reach this tipping point and when infection rates start to remit.
targetString: Aynol nyaube je maray nyauji feere hokkan matinolji to en jokki tobe ndu e to limtol nyau fuddi jippugo.

sourceString: The epidemiology of COVID-19 remains emergent.
targetString: Yahde nyau COVID-19 je rabbungel don tokkita.

sourceString: The registration-based nature of UK primary care means that we will be able to create a complete picture of the cumulative incidence and duration.
targetString: Bindol arandere suklare ha lesde UK yidi wi'ugo yo'o footi e wangina foto hawtirde larulaji fu be wakati man bo'o.

sourceString: The surveillance system should be able to identify areas where COVID-19 spread is taking place that might be suitable for trials of antiviral therapy.
targetString: Dabare aynol sey footi maandi wakkereji je COVID-19 don sankitta je footi wonda kandudum nder foondolji hurgol lekki viriisji.

sourceString: We could also follow up on the effectiveness or any adverse reactions to these medicines or vaccinations.
targetString: En tokkitan bo'o be kugal mala kala kujeji je lekki mala baatalji footi wangina je hannay nder bandu.

sourceString: Finally, early detection of a confirmed COVID-19 case has exemplified the rapid implementation of this enhanced surveillance in the national network.
targetString: Ha timminol, tawol nyau COVID-19 be wakati sappini jaawal nder huwidugo be dabare aynol ndu ha kawtirol lesdi fu.

sourceString: Safety of practices is our primary concern.
targetString: Jam wakkereji kude lati nummol amin je aranol.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC has operated for over 50 years and has been involved in collecting samples to monitor disease and vaccine effectiveness through the Hong Kong flu pandemic of 1968/69, the Russian flu of 1977/78, and the 2009 Swine flu pandemic.
targetString: RCGP RSC don huwa diga buri dubbi 50 e don no habda be moftugo leekuji ngam aynugo nyau be naffuda baatalgal ndamba rabbungel Hong Kong je 1968/69, ndamba Russiya je 1977/78, be nyau ndamba gaduuji je 2009.

sourceString: We are not aware of any increased risk to practice staff or other patients from involvement in surveillance.
targetString: Min kebbay larulaji gal huwobe wakkereji kude mala nyaube je don larni be aynol tawon.

sourceString: Pandemic preparedness is part of the role of the RCGP RSC.
targetString: Taskitol ngam nyau duniyaru lati bana kugal RCGP RSC feere.

sourceString: It is plausible that enhanced coding of information from contacts with the practices in RCGP RSC will reduce the likelihood of people who may be suspected COVID-19 cases being brought to the surgery inadvertently.
targetString: Lati aandotto yo'o lambugo matinolji diga ngidolji be kude ha RCGP RSC ustan naandol yimbe je footi mari nyau COVID-19 je be wadi bila fammugo ngam be seeka be.

sourceString: Where cases are detected unexpectedly, it is probably helpful for that patient, their contacts, and the practice to know.
targetString: Ha baabe je nyaube tawama bila ndenugo, footi mballita ha nyaudo ndu, yimbe je o ngidi be mabbe, wakkere kude ngam aandugo.

sourceString: The impact on practices has been to close for a day, if a case is found, for deep cleaning and then reopen.
targetString: Kugal man do kude mabban no nder nyalade gooto, to wodi nyaudo tawama, ngam leybugo nden mabbita.

sourceString: The principal limitations of our system are the number of data points.
targetString: Keerolji je aranool ha nder jaahargal amin lati limgal tobeji matinolji amin.

sourceString: We are collecting serology and virology data from 100 sites, which covers a small group of the population.
targetString: Min don mofta matinolji neebam iyam be je limtol yahde viriisji ha wakkereji 100, je don sudda geebe ummatore pammaron.

sourceString: This has been satisfactory for monitoring influenza, but we are not certain if this is a sufficiently large sample for the COVID-19 outbreak.
targetString: Ndu lati bodde ngam aynugo ndamba, amma en aanda be fakatre to ndu woni lekkuji deydey je he'atta ngam nyau COVID-19.

sourceString: Our sites (surveillance practices) are currently fixed, and it could be helpful to be able to rapidly onboard practices in regions where there are more cases.
targetString: Wakkereji amin (kude aynol) don aandin timmi, e footi naffa ngam jokkittugo wakkereji kude amin ha nder wakkereji je don mari nyaube jur.

sourceString: Currently, we will be reporting weekly.
targetString: Jonta, min wanginan ndu ha asawere fu.

sourceString: Our existing system can be enhanced to twice weekly, but maybe daily or hourly data should be our current approach.
targetString: Dabare jaahargal amin footi wurtama didi ha nder asawere, amma footi bo'o matinolji balde mala je njamdi lati nummol amin je jonta.

sourceString: Opportunistic sampling for serology in children younger than 10 years might be limited due to the overall reduced rate of blood tests in children.
targetString: Hoosugo leeku meere ngam larugo gildi ha bikkon je maray dubbi 10 footi ustama ngam lartol leeku iyam don usti ha mabbe.

sourceString: The extended surveillance using the RCGP RSC-PHE network for the emergent COVID-19 outbreak has been established rapidly.
targetString: Aynol je don yajjini gal huwidugo be hawtirol RCGP RSC-PHE ngam COVID-19 je wangi go nasti lau.

sourceString: The model of getting the appropriate informatics to enable capture of the required data has already been a success, with data recording starting the week the codes were created.
targetString: Dabare kebbugo dabare je kandudum je footi hoosa matinolji je don emmi lati bana titool, be hoccugo matinolji don fudda ha nder asawere wangol lambaji ndu.

sourceString: In addition, modifying the existing surveillance system to collect population data in a parallel way has also been effective.
targetString: Fahin bo'o, waylitugo dabare aynol je don wondi ndu ngam moftugo matinolji ummatore ha yakke feere bo'o lati naffuki.

sourceString: However, we are at present unsure as to whether the scale of this surveillance provides sufficient data to drive local containment strategies or if reporting infrequently meets the need of our information age.
targetString: Amma, ha jonta en aanda be fakatre to yajjol aynol ndu don hokka matinolji je he'atta ngam umminugo dabareji wondugo seera mala sappinugo be njibbol nder wakati don yahida be haaje dubbi matinolji amin.

sourceString: National Basketball Association suspends season due to COVID-19 concerns
targetString: National Basketball Association darni fiijirde maɗa ngam COVID-19

sourceString: On Wednesday, the United States' National Basketball Association (NBA) suspended its professional basketball season due to concerns regarding COVID-19.
targetString: Ha alarba, National Basketball Association (NBA) Lesɗe America darni fiijirde basketball aanduɓe ngam larulaji COVID-19.

sourceString: The NBA's decision followed a Utah Jazz player testing positive for the COVID-19 virus.
targetString: Hasduye NBA tokkiti fiijowo Utah Jazz feere larti bana mari viriis COVID-19.

sourceString: The NBA did not release the identity of the player in question in its announcement.
targetString: NBA matinay inde fiijowo ndu ha nder matinol maɗa.

sourceString: They did say he was not present at Chesapeake Energy Arena in Oklahoma City, where the Utah Jazz were to play against the Oklahoma City Thunder.
targetString: Mbiyotto o wonay no ha Chesapeake Energy Arena ha Oklahoma City, ha wakati je Utah Jazz fiijan no be Oklahoma City Thunder.

sourceString: According to its press release, the NBA was "suspending game play following the conclusion of [Wednesday's] schedule of games until further notice."
targetString: Ha limte hubaru ndu, NBA ɗon no "darnitta fiijirde ha ɓawo hasduye [Alarba] jaahargal fiijirde ha sey to matinol feere wurti fahin."

sourceString: The Jazz's game was cancelled, as was another NBA game Wednesday between the Sacramento Kings and the New Orleans Pelicans.
targetString: Fiijirde Jazz darnotto, bana fiijirde NBA feere ha Alarba ha kunde Sacramento Kings be New Orleans Pelicans.

sourceString: Other games scheduled for Wednesday were still held, according to NBC News.
targetString: Fiijirdeji feere je ɓe waɗi jaahargal ngal ngam Alarba saanjay no tawon, ha limte NBC News.

sourceString: The United States' other major basketball organization, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which runs college basketball, has cancelled its own tournament, March Madness, for both men's and women's leagues.
targetString: Fiijirde basketbaal maungel feere ha Lesɗe America, National Collegiate Athletic Association, je ɗon mari jaangirde basketball, darni fiijirde maɗa, March Madness, je worɓe be je rewɓe fu.

sourceString: According to Johns Hopkins University, as of Wednesday, there were at least 1,279 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the United States.
targetString: Ha limte Johns Hopkins University, ha Alarba, wodi pettum man nyauɓe 1 279 je ɗon aandi mari nyau COVID-19 ha Lesɗe America.

sourceString: CNBC reported there were at least 118,381 cases worldwide.
targetString: CNBC wi'i wodi nyimɓe je mari nyau ndu pettum man 118 381 ha nder duniyaru.

sourceString: US President Trump declares COVID-19 national emergency
targetString: Jagorɗo Lesɗe America Trump matini jaawal lesdi COVID-19

sourceString: On Friday, United States President Donald Trump declared a national emergency in response to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak.
targetString: Ha Jumɓare Jagorɗo Lesdi America Donald Trump matini jaawal lesdi bana jabbuye ha nyau viriis je wangi ndu.

sourceString: The move came two days after the World Health Organization declared the outbreak, which causes the COVID-19 disease, to be a pandemic.
targetString: Matinol ndu wangi ha ɓawo Geeɓe Duniyaru do Jam Ɓaandu, ko waɗi koronaviriis woni bana nyau duniyaru.

sourceString: The move gives the federal government access to around US$50 billion in extra funding to combat the pandemic, according to NBC News.
targetString: Yahde nde ɗon hokka jarfuye ha ngomna lesdi keɓɓ miliarji feere US$20 ngam nattinugo nyau, bana limte NBC News.

sourceString: The proclamation specifically said "the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States constitutes a national emergency" and said the national emergency began on March 1, almost two weeks before the proclamation itself.
targetString: Limte man wi'i "nyau COVID-19 ha nder Lesɗe America lati bana Jaawal lesdi fu" e wi'i jaawal lesdi fuɗɗi ha 1 Maars, ɓadi asaweji ɗiɗi hideko wangol ngel.

sourceString: The United States Department of Health and Human Services declared the outbreak a "public health emergency" on January 31.
targetString: Department of Health and Human Services ha Lesɗe America matini nyau ndu bana "jaawal jam ɓaandu ummatore" ha 31 Zaanviye.

sourceString: Trump did not place the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in charge of the government's response to COVID-19, which Politico reported left some experts in disaster management disappointed.
targetString: Trump hokkay ha juɗe Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) je jabbinata do COVID-19, je Politico matini bana acci aandooɓe siyasa do jaawal ha nder semtuɗum.

sourceString: Politico quoted Tim Manning, formerly a deputy administrator at FEMA, as saying "FEMA has an important role in coordinating the larger response to the crisis" and "[i]f there's an emergency, FEMA needs to be involved."
targetString: Politico limti ko Tim Manning, arduɗu ɗiɗaɓre ara ha FEMA, ba "FEMA ɗon mari kugal kanduɗum nder fadugo jabbuye do nyau duniyaru ndu" e "to wodi jaawal, sey nastina FEMA.

sourceString: Trump made the decision under provisions of the National Emergencies Act, amongst other governing authorities.
targetString: Trump hoosi jarfuye ndu do laahal National Emergencies Act, ha kunde arduɓe ngomna feere.

sourceString: The Trump administration also announced other efforts in response to COVID-19, including waiving the interest it collects on federal student loans and increasing U.S. strategic oil reserve oil purchases.
targetString: Ngomna Trump matini fahin bo'o dabareji feere ngam jabbugo do COVID-19, bana findinugo hakkilo ha do ceede jaangoɓe be ɓesdugo dabare neebam do siggorde neebam ngam sippugo.

sourceString: Impact of the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic on education
targetString: Saklere nyau koronaviriis 2019-20 do jaangirde

sourceString: The 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic has affected educational systems worldwide, leading to the widespread closures of schools and universities.
targetString: Nyau koronaviriis 2019-20 memmi jaahargal jaangirdeji ha nder duniyaru fu, je waɗi jaangirdeji be jam'iareji ɓurna fu nder duniyaru maɓɓi.

sourceString: As of 8 April 2020, approximately 1.716 billion learners have been affected due to school closures in response to COVID-19.
targetString: Ha 8 Aviiril 2020, deydey jaangoɓe miliarji 1.716 memmotto ngam maɓɓolji jaangirde ngam jabbuye ha COVID-19.

sourceString: According to UNESCO monitoring, 188 countries have implemented nationwide closures and 5 have implemented local closures, impacting about 99.4%  of the world's student population.
targetString: Ha larto UNESCO, lesɗe 188 maɓɓi dammuɗe maɓɓe do lesdi man fu be 5 maɓɓi ha wakkereji feere tan, ko memmi ɓadi 99.4% ummatore jaangoɓe duniyaru fu.

sourceString: On 23 March 2020, Cambridge International Examinations (CIE) released a statement announcing the cancellation of Cambridge IGCSE, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, and Cambridge Pre-U examinations for the May/June 2020 series across all countries.
targetString: Ha 23 Maars 2020, Cambridge International Examinations (CIE) wurtini matinol je ɗon no darna IGCSE Cambridge, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, be bindolji Cambridge Pre-U je Me/Zwiing 2020 ha nder lesɗe fu.

sourceString: International Baccalaureate exams have also been cancelled.School closures impact not only students, teachers, and families, but have far-reaching economic and societal consequences.
targetString: Bindi International Baccalaureate woni darnotto bo'o. Maɓɓolji jaangirde memmay tan jaangoɓe, jaanginooɓe, be caalaje, amma memmi bo'o jonde nder ummatore be siggordeji.

sourceString: School closures in response to COVID-19 have shed light on various social and economic issues, including student debt, digital learning, food insecurity, and homelessness, as well as access to childcare, health care, housing, internet, and disability services.
targetString: Maɓɓolji jaangirde ngam jabbuye ha COVID-19 ngewti do saɗirmaji ummatore be siggorde, be nyaamande jaangoɓe, ekkitol gal ordo, larula be nyamɗe, be wondugo bila saare, be nastirde ha suklare do ɓikkon, saare, internaati be kuɗe do yimɓe je mari nyau diga danyinki.

sourceString: The impact was more severe for disadvantaged children and their families, causing interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems, and consequent economic cost to families who could not work.In response to school closures, UNESCO recommended the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.
targetString: Ndu lati ɓuri sembe ɓikkon be caalage je maray dabareji feere, je ngaɗi ɓe darni jaangirde, maray nyamdu boɗɗe, mari larulaji ngam wala goɗɗo je suklata do ɓikkon, be asaarji je caalaje je footay huwa ɗon matta. Jabbugo ha maɓɓolji jaangirde UNESCO ɗon feela jaahargal ekkitolji daayindi e emmolji jaangirde be daaldalji je jaangirdeji be jaangoɓe footi jokka jaangoɓe gal dabareji daayindi e darni jaangirde.

sourceString: Efforts to stem the spread of COVID-19 through non-pharmaceutical interventions and preventive measures such as social-distancing and self-isolation have prompted the widespread closure of primary, secondary, and tertiary schooling in over 100 countries.Previous outbreaks of infectious diseases have prompted widespread school closings around the world, with varying levels of effectiveness.
targetString: Dabareji darnugo sankittol COVID-19 gal dabareji je wonday gal lekki mala aynol bana dayol ummatore be wondugo ha seera be hoore mum yaawini maɓɓol jaangirdeji aranool, ɗiɗiɗaɓool, be tataɓool ha nder lesɗe 100. Nyauji warango yaawini maɓɓolji jaangirde ha der nder duniyaru, be yajjol ndu ɗon saanja be wakkere e lesdi.

sourceString: Mathematical modelling has shown that transmission of an outbreak may be delayed by closing schools.
targetString: Sappinol limtol sappini yo' o sallinol nyau footi ɗaaya gal maɓɓugo cuuɗi jaangirdeji.

sourceString: However, effectiveness depends on the contacts children maintain outside of school.
targetString: Amma, goongakku man wondi do footi ngaɗa ha ɓawo suudu jaangirde.

sourceString: School closures may be effective when enacted promptly.
targetString: Maɓɓolji jaangirde footi naffa to waɗatto be wakati.

sourceString: If school closures occur late relative to an outbreak, they are less effective and may not have any impact at all.
targetString: To maɓɓolji jaangirde yotti be ɗaayol, marata naffuda jur e footi marata sembe sam ma.

sourceString: Additionally, in some cases, the reopening of schools after a period of closure has resulted in increased infection rates.
targetString: Fahin bo'o, ha wakkere feere, maɓɓitol jaangirdeji ha ɓawo wakati maɓɓol waɗi limtolji nyauɓe ɓesdi.

sourceString: As closures tend to occur concurrently with other interventions such as public gathering bans, it can be difficult to measure the specific impact of school closures.During the 1918-1919 influenza pandemic in the United States, school closures and public gathering bans were associated with lower total mortality rates.
targetString: Bana maɓɓolji ɗon yahida be dabareji feere bana haɗɗol mofturde ummatore, footi lato caɗɗum foondugo ko maɓɓolji jaangirde ndu wadi. Ha wakati nyau ndamba  ha 1918-1919 ha nder Lesɗe America, maɓɓolji jaangirde be haɗɗol mofturde ummatore yahidi no be limtol mayɓe je wonay jur.

sourceString: Cities that implemented such interventions earlier had greater delays in reaching peak mortality rates.
targetString: Berniji je huwidi be dabareji ndu diga fuɗɗam man daayi no ngam jokkittugo limtolji mayde ndu.

sourceString: Schools closed for a median duration of 4 weeks according to a study of 43 US cities' response to the Spanish Flu.
targetString: Jaangirdeji maɓɓakke ha nder deydey asaweji 4 bana sappinol ekkitol jabbuji berni Lesɗe America 43.

sourceString: School closures were shown to reduce morbidity from the Asian flu by 90% during the 1957–58 outbreak, and up to 50% in controlling influenza in the US, 2004–2008.Multiple countries successfully slowed the spread of infection through school closures during the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
targetString: Maɓɓolji jaangirde woni no bana ustan limtol mayde nyauɓe Ndamba Asia je 1957-58, e ha 50% ngam lartugo nyau ha Lesɗe America, 2004-2008. Lesɗe ɗuɗɗum ɗaayini yahde sankittol nyau gal maɓɓolji jaangirde ha yakke nyau H1N1 2009.

sourceString: School closures in the city of Oita, Japan, were found to have successfully decreased the number of infected students at the peak of infection; however closing schools was not found to have significantly decreased the total number of infected students.
targetString: Maɓɓolji jaangirde ha nder berniwol Oita, Japan, tawama bana ustini limtol jaangoɓe je nyauɗo; amma maɓɓolji jaangirde latay dabare ustugo limtol jaangoɓe fu je mari nyau ndu be gonga.

sourceString: Mandatory school closures and other social distancing measures were associated with a 29% to 37% reduction in influenza transmission rates.
targetString: Maɓɓolji jaangirde be dabareji daayol ummatore yahidi no be jippol 29% ha 37% be limtol sallinol ndamba.

sourceString: Early school closures in the United States delayed the peak of the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
targetString: Maɓɓolji jaangirde be wakati ha nder Lesɗe America ɗaayini nyau ndamba H1N1 je 2009.

sourceString: Despite the overall success of closing schools, a study of school closures in Michigan found that "district level reactive school closures were ineffective."During the swine flu outbreak in 2009 in the UK, in an article titled "Closure of schools during an influenza pandemic" published in the Lancet Infectious Diseases, a group of epidemiologists endorsed the closure of schools in order to interrupt the course of the infection, slow further spread and buy time to research and produce a vaccine.
targetString: Ko to cuuɗi jaangirde fu maɓɓi, ekkitol do maɓɓolji jaangirde ha Michigan sappini yo'o "maɓɓolji jaangirde ha nder distrik maray naffuda." Ha wakati nyau ndamba gaduru ha 2009 ha Lesɗe Inglisiya, wodi batakkewol feere je hoore man "Closure of schools during an influenza pandemic" je wurti ha nder Lancet Infectious Diseases, geeɓe aandooɓe nyau je ɗon raɓɓa hasdi maɓɓolji jaangirde ngam darnugo yahde nyau ndu, ɗaayina, e heɓɓa wakati ngam wurtinugo baatal.

sourceString: Having studied previous influenza pandemics including the 1918 flu pandemic, the influenza pandemic of 1957 and the 1968 flu pandemic, they reported on the economic and workforce effect school closure would have, particularly with a large percentage of doctors and nurses being women, of whom half had children under the age of 16.
targetString: Ngam ɓe jaangi nyauji ndamba je sallingobe nyauji ndambe 1918, nyau ndamba 1957 be nyau ndamba 1968, ɓe matini do ko maɓɓolji jaangirde footi mara bana saɗirma do siggorde ceede mala jonde ummatore, ɓurna bo'o be limtol lekkitoɓe be sukloɓe do jam ɓaandu je woni rewɓe, je reeta maɓɓe ɗon mari ɓikkon je maray duɓɓi 16.

sourceString: They also looked at the dynamics of the spread of influenza in France during French school holidays and noted that cases of flu dropped when schools closed and re-emerged when they re-opened.
targetString: Fahin bo'o, ɓe lari yahde sankittol ndamba ha Faraansa ha wakati siwtare jaangirdeji maɓɓe e fammi yo'o nyauɓe ndamba usti ha yakke jaangirdeji maɓɓi e ɓesdi ha yakke je jaangirdeji maɓɓitti.

sourceString: They noted that when teachers in Israel went on strike during the flu season of 1999–2000, visits to doctors and the number of respiratory infections dropped by more than a fifth and more than two fifths respectively.
targetString: Ɓe fammi yo'o ha yakke je jaanginoɓe turti ha akati ndamba ha 1999-2000, ngilli ha lekkitoɓe be limgal nyauji pofɗe usti be ɓuri reeta be ɗiɗi nder joowey.

sourceString: For schools and childcare facilities, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.
targetString: Ko larni jaangirdeji be wakkereji suklugo do ɓikkon, Ɗowirɗe Aynol e Lartol Jam Ɓaandu Lesɗe America feeli maɓɓol ha nder wakkati seeɗa tan ngam laɓɓugo mala laɓɓinugo to wodi nyaudo no ha nder wakkere jaangirde bila larugo sankittol nyau ha cakka ummatore.

sourceString: When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as cancelling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.
targetString: To wodi dabare sallinol seeɗa ha deydey, dabareji dayol be ummatore footi naffa bana darnugo wurtol jaangirde ha ngilli, moftude, be kawtirdeji maungel bana ekkitolji espor, gimmol mala nyammugo ha suudu nyaɗe, ɓesdugo baabe ha kunde koroomje lartugo wakati yottugo be je hottugo, darnugo ngilli meere-meere, be neldugo jaangoɓe je bana mari ndamba ha suudu lekki feere.

sourceString: When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.
targetString: To wodi sallinol kanduɗum ha cakka ummatore, ɓesdugo do dabareji dayol ummatore, darnolji jaangirde ha nder wakati juttungel sey lartotto.

sourceString: On 26 January, China instituted measures to contain the COVID-19 outbreak which included extending the Spring Festival holiday to contain the outbreak.
targetString: Ha 26 Zaanviye, Cayna wurtini dabareji ngam darnugo nyau COVID-19 je larni yarɓugo julde Spring Festival ha ɓawo ngam darnugo nyau ndu.

sourceString: Universities and schools around the country closed.
targetString: Jam'iareji be jaangirdeji ha nder tarde ndu maɓɓakke.

sourceString: On 23 February, Iran's Ministry of Health announced the closure of universities, higher educational institutions and schools in several cities and provinces.
targetString: Ha 23 Feviriye, Arduɗo Jam ɓaandu Iran matini maɓɓol jam'iareji, jaangirdeji maungel be jaangirdeji ha nder lamordeji ɗuɗɗum.

sourceString: On 3 March, UNESCO released the first global numbers on school closures and affected students.
targetString: Ha 3 Maars, UNESCO wurtini arandere limgal jaangirdeji je ɗon maɓɓi be ɓikkon je ɗon memmi.

sourceString: It reported that 13 countries had enacted preventive measures including the temporary closure of schools and universities, impacting 290.5 million students around the world.
targetString: Matinama yo'o lesɗe 13 hoosi dabareji aynol bana maɓɓolji jaangirde be jam'iareji nder wakati seeɗa, ko memmi jaangoɓe milionji 290.5 ha nder duniyaru.

sourceString: In reaction, UNESCO called on countries to support affected students and families and facilitate large-scale inclusive distance learning programmes.
targetString: Bana jabbuye, UNESCO ewni lesɗe ngam wallugo jaangoɓe be caalaje je ɗon memmi e hasda ngam jaahargalji ekkitol daayinde.

sourceString: On 4 March, the Italian government ordered the full closure of all schools and universities nationwide as Italy reached 100 deaths.
targetString: Ha 4 Maars, ngomna Italy hasdi maɓɓolji jaangirdeji be jam'iareji fu ha do lesdi Italy bana yimɓe 100 maynama ngam nyau ndu.

sourceString: In doing so, Italy became one of 22 countries on three continents which had announced or implemented school closures.
targetString: Gal dabare ndu, Italy lati lesɗe 22 ha do hawtirde lesdi tati je matini mala hasdi ngam maɓɓugo jaangirdeji.

sourceString: On 5 March, the majority of learners affected by COVID-19 emergency measures were located in China, with 233 million learners affected, followed by Japan at 16.5 million and Iran at 14.5 million.
targetString: Ha 5 Maars, ɓurna jaangoɓe je dabareji jaawal COVID-19 memmi ɓe wondi no ha Cayna, jaangoɓe milionji 233 memmotto, tokkiti be Japan be milionji 16.5 e Iran be milionji 14.5.

sourceString: By 10 March, one in five students worldwide was "staying away from school due to the COVID-19 crisis" while another one in four was barred from higher education institutions.
targetString: Ha 10 Maars, gooto nder jaangoɓe joowey woni "dayiɗum be jaangirde ngam nyau COVID-19" ha wakati feere gooto nder jaangoɓe nay fartakke ha jaangirdeji je maungel.

sourceString: On 13 March, governments in 49 countries announced or implemented school closures, including 39 countries which closed schools nationwide and 22 countries with localised school closures.
targetString: Ha 13 Maars, ngomna'en ha nder lesɗe 49 matini mala hasdi maɓɓolji jaangirde, be lesɗe 39 je maɓɓi jaangirde ha do lesdi maɓɓe fu e lesɗe 22 darni jaangirde ha wakkere feere tan.

sourceString: By 16 March, this figure increased from 49 to 73 countries according to UNESCO.
targetString: Ha 16 Maars, limgal ngel ummi diga lesɗe 49 ha 73 ha matinol UNESCO.

sourceString: By 19 March, 50% of students worldwide were affected by school closures, corresponding to nationwide closures in 102 countries and local closures in 11 countries affecting 850 million children and youth.
targetString: Ha 19 Maars, 50% jaangoɓe memmotto ngam maɓɓolji jaangirde, je waɗi limgal man ha nder duniyaru fu ha lesɗe 102 be darnolji 11 ha wakkereji feere, ko memmi ɓikkon be sukaɓe milionji 850.

sourceString: By 20 March, over 70% of the world's learners were impacted by closures, with 124 country-wide school closures.
targetString: Ha 20 Maars, ɓuri 70% jaangoɓe ha nder duniyaru memmotto be maɓɓolji, be maɓɓolji 124 ha nder lesɗe fu.

sourceString: On 23 March, all Nigerian school were found to have been closed down by Nigerian government, markets as well as companies were closed down and children were forbidden by parents to step out of their homes.
targetString: Ha 23 Maars, ngomna Nigeriya maɓɓi jaangirdeji fu ha do lesdi maɗa, lumoji be cuuɗi maungel bo'o maɓɓakke e baabiraɓe haɗɗi ɓikkon maɓɓe wurtugo ha yaasi.

sourceString: On 26 March, all New Zealand schools and universities have been closed down across the country.
targetString: Ha 26 Maars, jaangirdeji be jam'ireji New Zealand fu maɓɓakke ha do lesdi man fu.

sourceString: The government has imposed a two-week holiday, allowing schools to transition to forms of distant teaching as soon as possible.
targetString: Ngomna hasdi asawereji ɗiɗi ngam wondugo ha saare, ngam heɓɓa jaangirdeji salla ha dabareji jaangirde dayindi bana ko wowa.

sourceString: Universities have closed for one week, but resumed with online teaching afterwards.
targetString: Jam'iareji maɓɓakke nder asawere gooto, amma fuɗɗiti be jaangirde do internati ha ɓawo man.

sourceString: Other school services remain open, but teaching is restricted to distant learning.
targetString: Kuɗe jaangirdeji lati maɓɓitama, amma jaangirde joɗɗi do je dayindi go.

sourceString: By 27 March, nearly 90 percent of the world's student population was out of class.
targetString: Ha 27 Maars, ɓadi 90% hawtirde ummatore jaangoɓe ha duniyaru wurtakke suudu jaangirde.

sourceString: Regions with schools remaining open included Taiwan, Singapore, Australia, Sweden, and some U.S. states.
targetString: Wakkereji be jaangirdeji je wonotto maɓɓitama ha Taiwan, Singapore, Australia, Sweden e feere'en ha Lesɗe America.

sourceString: By 29 March, more than 1.5 billion children and other students were affected by nationwide school closures.
targetString: Ha 29 Maars, ɓuri ɓikkon miliarji 1.5 be jaangoɓe feere memmotto ngam maɓɓolji jaangirdeji ha do lesdi fu.

sourceString: Others were disrupted by localized closures.
targetString: Feere'en darnotto ngam maɓɓolji nder wakkere nde.

sourceString: Until April 6, holidays were extended in all secondary schools of Turkmenistan.
targetString: Ha 6 Aviiril, siwtare ɓesdotto ha nder jaangirdeji diɗaɓool fu ha Turkmenistan.

sourceString: An order signed by the Ministry of Education as a preventative measure aims to prevent the spread of respiratory diseases in connection with the WHO coronavirus pandemic.
targetString: Umrore feere je Arduɗo Jaangirde waɗi jungo do man bana dabare aynol yiɗi darnugo sankittol nyauji pofɗe be nyau koronaviriis WHO.

sourceString: 10 countries have localised schools closures, UNESCO estimates  473,933,356  learners are potentially at risk (pre-primary to upper-secondary education) and 77,938,904 learners are potentially at risk in tertiary education.
targetString: Lesɗe 10 maɓɓi suudu jaangirde ha wakkereji feere, UNESCO matini yo'o footi jaangoɓe 473 933 356 maran larulaji (diga jaarne ha jaangirde ɗiɗaɓre) be jaangooɓe 77 938 904 footi mara larulaji ha jaangirde tataɓool.

sourceString: Note: Figures correspond to total number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8] who could be affected should localised closures become countrywide.
targetString: Mandol: Limgal larni hawtirde jaangoɓe je windama ha jaarne, aranool, ɗiɗaɓool les, be ɗiɗaɓool do [ISCED yaɓɓorde 0 ha 3], bana ha yaɓɓorde jaangirde tataɓool  [ISCED yaɓɓorde 5 ha 8] je footi memmotto to maɓɓolji hoosi lesdi fu.

sourceString: Enrolment figures based on latest UNESCO Institute of Statistics data.
targetString: Limgal nastukki do ragare matinolji Institute of Statistics UNESCO.

sourceString: School closures in response to the COVID-19 pandemic have shed a light on numerous issues affecting access to education, as well as broader socio-economic issues.
targetString: Maɓɓolji jaangideji ngam jabbuye ha COVID-19 ngewti do kujeji jur je saklatta nastirde ha dabare jaangirde, be larulaji ummatore be je siggorde ceede.

sourceString: As of March 12, more than 370 million children and youth are not attending school because of temporary or indefinite country wide school closures mandated by governments in an attempt to slow the spread of COVID-19.
targetString: Ha 12 Maars, ɓuri ɓikkon be sukkaɓe milionji 370 wala yahugo ha suudu jaangirde ngam ngomna'en wangini umrore do darnol jaangirdeji ha nder lesdi ha nder wakati seeɗa mala deydey ngam ɗaayinugo sankittol COVID-19.

sourceString: As of 29 March, nearly 90% of the world's learners were impacted by closures.Even when school closures are temporary, it carries high social and economic costs.
targetString: Ha 29 Maars, ɓadi 90% jaangoɓe duniyaru memmotto ngam maɓɓol. Ko to ɓe darni jaangirdeji ndu nder wakati seeɗa tan, ɗon ngada majjinol ceede jur ha nder ummatore be siggorde.

sourceString: The disruptions they cause affect people across communities, but their impact is more severe for disadvantaged children and their families including interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems and consequent economic cost to families who cannot work.
targetString: Darnolji je ɓe wadi ɗon memma yimɓe ha nder ummatore, amma kuɗe man latan caɗɗum ha ɓikkon be caalaje je maray dabare feere bana ekkitol, nyamɗe je kalluɗum, saɗirmaji ɓikkon be majjol ceede je ɗon tokki ha caalaje je footay huwa sam.

sourceString: Working parents are more likely to miss work when schools close in order to take care of their children, incurring wage loss in many instances and negatively impacting productivity.
targetString: Baabiraɓe je ɗon huwa ɓurna yahatta kugal to jaangirdeji maɓɓi ngam suklugo do ɓikkon maɓɓe, ko ɗon waɗa ceede lewru maɓɓe ustan ha nder wakkere jur e ko ɗon memma marde maɓɓe.

sourceString: Localised school closures place burdens on schools as parents and officials redirect children to schools that are open.
targetString: Maɓɓolji jaangirde ha wakkereji feere tan ndu ɗon hokka doongal ha baabiraɓe be arduɓe neldan ɓikkon ha jaangirdeji je ɗon maɓɓiti.

sourceString: Women often represent a large share of health-care workers and often cannot attend work because of childcare obligations that result from school closures.
targetString: Rewɓe ɓurna fu on suklatta do nyauɓe ha cuuɗi jam ɓaandu e ha yakke feere footay wonda ha kugal ngam suklugo do ɓikkon maɓɓe je ɗon saare ngam jaangirdeji ɗon maɓɓi.

sourceString: This means that many medical professionals are not at the facilities where they are most needed during a health crisis.
targetString: Ndu yiɗi wi'ugo yo'o huwooɓe ngam jam ɓaandu wonday ha wakkereji kugal je ɓe ɓuri marugo haaje maɓɓe ha ton.

sourceString: Lack of access to technology or fast, reliable internet access can prevent students in rural areas and from disadvantaged families.
targetString: Dabare je wala ngam keɓɓugo nastirde ha teknik mala ha internati je ɗon yaawa footi haɗɗa jaangoɓe ha kawyeji e je caalaje maɓɓe ɗon laffi.

sourceString: Lack of access to technology or good internet connectivity is an obstacle to continued learning, especially for students from disadvantaged families.
targetString: Dabare je wala ngam keɓɓugo nastirde ha teknik mala internati je boɗɗe lati haɗɗol nder ekkitol, ɓurna bo'o ha jaangoɓe je ummi caalaje je ɗon laffi masitin.

sourceString: In response to school closures caused by COVID-19, UNESCO recommends the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.To aid in slowing the transmission of COVID-19, hundreds of libraries have temporarily closed.
targetString: Bana jabbuye ha maɓɓolji jaangirde ngam COVID-19 , UNESCO feeli dabare jaahargalji jaangirde dayindi e applikasioji be baabe ekkitolji je jaangirdeji be jaanginoɓe footi huwida do ndu ngam memmugo jaangoɓe dayindi e usta darnol ekkitol. Ngam wallugo nder ɗaayinugo sallinol COVID-19, cuuɗi ekkitolji temere do temere maɓɓakke tawon.

sourceString: In the United States, numerous major cities announced public library closures, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, and New York City, affecting 221 libraries.
targetString: Ha nder Lesɗe America, berniji maungel jur matini maɓɓugo cuuɗi ekkitol ummatore, bana Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, be New York City, memmi cuuɗi ekkitol 221.

sourceString: For students without internet at home, this increases the difficulty of keeping up with distance learning.
targetString: Ha jaangoɓe je maray internati ha saare, ndu ɓesdi saɗirma tokkitugo be ekkitol gal internati.

sourceString: School closures puts a strain on parents and guardians to provide childcare and manage distance learning while children are out of school.
targetString: Maɓɓolji jaangirde watti doongal do baabiraɓe be fadooɓe ngam suklugo do ɓikkon e waɗa dabare heɓɓa ɓikkon jokkita ekkitol do hawo bana ɓe wala ha suudu jaangirde fahin.

sourceString: In the absence of alternative options, working parents often leave children alone when schools close and this can lead to risky behaviours, including increased influence of peer pressure and substance abuse.
targetString: To wala dabareji feere, baabiraɓe je ɗon huwa ɓurna acca ɓikkon feere maɓɓe ha saare to bana jaangirde maɓɓakke e ndu footi yarna ha gikkuji kalluɗum, bana raɓɓol gikku sobiraaɓe be hoosugo wikkere.

sourceString: Many children worldwide rely on free or discounted meals at schools.
targetString: Ɓikkon ɗuɗɗum ha nder duniyaru fu ɗon limma do dabare nyamɓe meere mala je kooyɗum ha jaangirde.

sourceString: When schools close, nutrition is compromised.Nutrition plays a critical role in cognitive development and academic performance for children.In Washington State, around 45% of the states 1.1 million students enrolled in traditional public and charter schools qualify for subsidised school meals.
targetString: To jaangirdeji maɓɓi, nyamɗe wonan caɗɗum. Nyamdu lati kanduɗum ha nder yahde ekkitol e aandal ɓikkon. Ha Lesdi Washington, deydey 45% milionre 1.1 jaangoɓe lesɗe je ɗon windi ha nder jaangirde ngomna mala feere mari jarfuye heɓɓugo nyamɗe je ɗon buuti ha jaangirde.

sourceString: At least 520,000 students and their families may be affected by food insecurity as a result of school closures.School lunch programmes are the second-biggest anti-hunger initiative in the United States after food stamps.
targetString: Pettum man jaangoɓe 520 000 be caalaje maɓɓe footi yara bone ngam heɓɓugo nyamdu ngam maɓɓolji jaangirde. Jaahargalji nyamdu ha jaangirde lati bana ɗiɗaɓool dabare je ɗon haɓɓa ngam weelo ha Lesɗe America ha ɓawo batakkeji nyamdu.

sourceString: Every year, nearly 30 million children rely on schools to provide free or low-cost meals including breakfast, lunch, snacks, and even dinner.In Alabama, where state-wide school closures as of 18 March have affected over 720,000 students, the state Superintendent announced that staff in schools disproportionately affected by poverty would create meal distribution networks to provide food for students who rely on school lunches.
targetString: Ha nder hittande fu, ɓadi ɓikkon milionji 30 ɗon ndeni do jaangirde ngam soddugo nyamdu kooɗum bana nyamdu fajiri, naange, je jiba, be je kikiɗe fu. Ha Alabama je ɓe maɓɓi jaangirdeji ha nder wakkere ndu diga 18 Maars memmi jaangoɓe 720000, Superintendent lesdi matini yo'o huwooɓe ha jaangirdeji je laffere ɗon memma ɓe sey ngaɗa dabare keɓɓugo baabe hokkugo nyamdu ha jaangoɓe je ɗon no mari tammunde maɓɓe do nyamdu jaangirde.

sourceString: School closures negatively impact student learning outcomes.
targetString: Maɓɓol jaangirde ɗon memma sappinolji ekkitol jaangowo.

sourceString: Schooling provides essential learning and when schools close, children and youth are deprived opportunities for growth and development.
targetString: Yahugo ha suudu jaangirde ɗon hokka aandal kaanduɗum ha jaangowo e to jaangirde maɓɓi, ɓikkon be sukkaɓe maray sa'aji mawnol be aandal.

sourceString: The disadvantages are disproportionate for under-privileged learners who tend to have fewer educational opportunities beyond school.Student drop-out rates tend to increase as an effect of school closures due to the challenge of ensuring all students return to school once school closures ends.
targetString: Larulaji ɗuɗɗuni jaangooɓe je maray sa'a bana feere'en je bana tammi heɓɓugo aandal bana je o heɓɓatta no ha suudu jaangirde. Limtol jaangoɓe je accan jaangirde ɗon ɓesda ngam maɓɓolji jaangirdeji ngam saɗirma emmugo ha jaangoɓe fu lora suudu jaangirde to maɓɓitama fahin.

sourceString: This is especially true of protracted closures.Schools are hubs of social activity and human interaction.
targetString: Ndu lati gonga to ɓe juttini maɓɓolji ndu.Jaangirdeji lati bana cakkare kuɗe ummatore be wondugo oya be oya.

sourceString: When schools are closed, many children and youth miss out of on social contact that is essential to learning and development.When schools close parents are often asked to facilitate the learning of children at home and can struggle to perform this task.
targetString: To jaangirdeji ɗon maɓɓi, ɓikkon be sukkaɓe ɗuɗɗum footay ngida be ummatore, kanjuum je woni no kanduɗum nder ekkitol e aandal. To jaangirdeji maɓɓakke ɓe ɗon emma baabiraɓe emmotto ngam wallugo ɓingel be ekkitol ha saare e footi haɓda ngam waɗɗugo ndu.

sourceString: This is especially true for parents with limited education and resources.
targetString: Ndu woni gonga ha baabiraɓe je jaangay jur mala je ɗon laffi.

sourceString: Potential impacts of school closures and reliance on distance learning are not addressed in federal acts of legislation at this time.
targetString: Saɗirmaji je maɓɓinolji jaangirde e ekkitolji gal internati ndu limtay ha nder umrore lesdi ha wakati nde.

sourceString: Formal education — as opposed to informal education or non-formal education — tends to refer to schools, colleges, universities and training institutions.
targetString: Jaangirde je aandin, je hawtaw je jaangirde feere mala je aandaka, ɗon larni suudu jaangirdeji, collegeji, jam'iareji be jaangirdeji ekkitol.

sourceString: A 1974 report by the World Bank defined formal education as the following:Formal education: the hierarchically structured, chronologically graded ‘education system', running from primary school through the university and including, in addition to general academic studies, a variety of specialised programmes and institutions for full-time technical and professional training.The majority of data collected on the number of students and learners impacted by COVID-19 has been calculated based on the closure of formal education systems.
targetString: Batakkewol feere je 1974 gal Siggorde Ceede Duniyaru limti jaangirde je ɗon aandi bana: Jaangirde je ɗon aandi: dabare jaangirde je ɗon yaha be yaɓɓorde e be wakati, fuɗɗan diga jaandirde aranool ha jam'iare be, hawti be kanjuum ekkitolji aandal feere-feere, jaahargalji feerejo be jaangirdeji je larni kujeji makanaki be kugal. Ɓurna matinolji je moftama do limgal jaangoɓe be ekkitoɓe je COVID-19 memmi larni maɓɓol jaahargalji jaangirde je ɗon aandi.

sourceString: The UNESCO Institute for Statistics provides figures on students impacted by COVID-19 corresponding to the number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8].
targetString: UNESCO Institute for Statistics ɗon hokka limgal jaangoɓe je COVID-19 memmi je lati limgal jaangoɓe je inde maɓɓe ɗon windi ha jaangirde temma je jaarne, aranool, ɗiɗaɓool les, ɗiɗaɓol do [ISCED yaɓɓorde 0 ha 3], be tataɓool [ISCED yaɓɓorde 5 ha 8].

sourceString: Early childhood educational programmes are usually designed for children below the age of 3 and may refer to preschools, nursery schools, kindergartens, and some day care programmes.
targetString: Jaahargalji ɓikkon pamarron wondi ngam ɓikkon je maray duɓɓi tati e footi ewna ndu hiddeko jaangirde, jaarne, kindergartens be jaahargalji suklare ha balɗe feere.

sourceString: While many primary and secondary schools have closed around the world due to COVID-19, measures impacting early childhood educational programmes have varied.
targetString: Ha wakati je jaangirdeji aranool be ɗiɗaɓool maɓɓakke ha nder duniyaru ngam COVID-19, dabareji je memmotto jaahargalji ɓikkon pamarron saanji.

sourceString: In some countries and territories, preschools and day cares are considered necessary services and have not closed in tandem with broader school closure measures.In the United States, the Washington State Department of Children, Youth, and Families encouraged child care and early learning centres to stay open.
targetString: Ha nder lesɗe feere be wakkereji, hiddeko jaangirde be balɗe suklare lati bana kanduɗum e ɗon maɓɓiti ha jonta be dabareji jaangirde mawngel ɗon maɓɓi. Ha Lesɗe America, Geeɓe lesdi Washington ngam Ɓikkon, Sukkaɓe be Caalaje ɗon yardi suklugo do ɓingel be wakkereji ndu ɗon maɓɓitti.

sourceString: Some school districts may offer alternative child care options, prioritising the children of first responders and healthcare workers.
targetString: Distrikji jaangirde feere footi hokka dabareji feere, e ɗon hokka arandere sa'a ha ɓe'en je ɗon haɓɓa ngam jam ɓaandu yimɓe be huwooɓe cuuɗi lekki.

sourceString: The governor of Maryland mandated that specific child care services remain open for the children of emergency personnel while Washington State and California have left it to the discretion of care providers.
targetString: Ngomna Maryland matini yo'o kuɗe suklare do ɓikkon wonan maɓɓittama ngam ɓikkon yimɓe je ɗon huwa ha suudu jam ɓaandu ha wakati man Lesdi Washington be California accini ndu ha nder jaahargal sukloɓe do jam ɓaandu.

sourceString: California Governor Gavin Newsom explained his state's position, saying “We need our child care facilities, our daycare centers, to operate to absorb the impact of these school closures.”
targetString: Ngomna California Gavin Newsom ngewti do ko lesdi mako ɗon waɗa, be wi'ugo "Min ngiɗi wakkereji suklare do ɓikkon amin, wakkereji balɗe, ngam huwida ngam ustugo saɗirma je maɓɓol jaangirdeji amin".

sourceString: Colorado has encouraged the development of "tool kits" for parents to use at home to emulate the lessons children would have received in their early learning programmes.In Japan, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe closed all schools throughout the country until April 8, however, children's daycare facilities were excluded.
targetString: Colorado sembintini wurtinugo "tool kits" ngam baabiraɓe je huwida be man ha saare je foondata ekkitolji je ɓikkon maɓɓe jaɓɓan no ha nder jaahargalji ekkitol maɓɓe.

sourceString: In early March, five adults associated with a nursing facility for preschool children in Kobe tested positive for coronavirus.
targetString: Ha fuɗɗam Maars, mawɓe joowey je ɗon no sukla do ɓikkon ha jaangirde jaarne ha Kobe larti ɗon mari nyau koronaviriis.

sourceString: After testing over one hundred children at the facility, a preschool student was found to be carrying the virus.

sourceString: Students enrolled in higher education programmes at colleges, universities, and community colleges are often refereed to in countries such as United States as "college students."The closure of colleges and universities has widespread implications for students, faculty, administrators, and the institutions themselves.
